profileText: A Representative from California; born in Janesville, Rock County, Wis., May 18, 1851; moved to California in 1859 with his parents, who settled in Stockton; attended the public schools in Stockton and Brayton College, Oakland, in 1869; was graduated from the University of California at Berkeley in 1873; served as lieutenant colonel on the Governor's staff in 1873 and 1874; deputy district attorney in 1873 and 1874; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1874 and commenced practice in Stockton; served as first lieutenant in the California National Guard and was promoted to major of the line; elected as a Democrat to the Forty-eighth Congress (March 4, 1883-March 3, 1885); declined to be a candidate for reelection in 1884; appointed police and fire commissioner of Stockton in 1889; member of the board for drafting the city charter in 1889; Governor of California 1894-1898; resumed the practice of law in San Francisco; died in Stockton, Calif., July 30, 1908; interment in Rural Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Budd, James Herbert. Chinese immigration. Washington: [Government Printing Office], 1884.
------. Remarks of Hon. James H. Budd, of California, in the House of Representatives, Wednesday, March 5, 1884. [Washington: Government Printing Office], 1884.
Peterson, Eric Falk. "The End of an Era: California's Gubernatorial Election of 1894." Pacific Historical Review 38 (May 1969): 141-56.

researchRecord.name: 1884, 1 volume.
researchRecord.description: A letterpress copy book dating from February 1 - August 27, 1884, containing personal, business, and political correspondence, of James H. Budd.

researchRecord.name: In the California Department of Public Instruction records, 1895, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A life diploma of the grammar grade awarded to Juliet H. Lumbard, June 10, 1895. The diploma is signed by James H. Budd, Governor of California.

researchRecord.name: In the Miles John Nightingale daybook, 1881-1891, 1 volume.
In the Restoration to citizenship, State of California, Executive Department, 1896-1898, 1 volume.
researchRecord.description: The volume includes prison release records by the California governor James H. Budd, and signed by W.T. Sesnon, deputy.

researchRecord.name: In the Richard C. Rust papers, 1896-1902, 1 oversize folder.
researchRecord.description: Includes miscellaneous papers, including two commissions as Judge of the Superior Court of California for Amador County, 1896 and 1902, signed by James H. Budd.

researchRecord.name: In the John Stanton Political Campaign Collection, 1860-2007, amount unknown.
1883-1895, 1 folder.
researchRecord.description: Four pieces of correspondence, including one sent autographed letter, pertaining to James Budd, Governor of California, from 1895 to 1899.
